so let's dive let's dive deeper to the physical attributes of ethernet the most popular ethernet cables are
copper cables that use either fast ethernet which is 100 megabits or gigabit ethernet these two files have
very different encodings on the physical layer in fast ethernet the encoding uses a five bit symbols on
the wire for every four bits of data this leaves space for additional control symbols such as start and end of frame
the rest of the symbols are invalid gigabit encoding is different but it also uses a similar approach
where it has a start and end frame symbol the important thing to understand is that there is no error detection at this
layer except for detecting invalid signals an inherited cable is never connected
directly to a cpu or microcontroller but rather it's usually connected to an ethernet phi chip that fight chip is usually
connected to the cpu using a hardware interface called gmii or rdmi the job of the file chip is
to translate the ethernet symbols from the wire into a parallel 8-bit bus carrying our familiar layer 2 data bytes
alongside the rx data valid signal used for delimiting the frames so while the file layers so while on the

these explicit signals only affect the rx data valid signal and that signal is only part of what the

here we can see what data actually appears on the wire as part of the internet frame and how it's handled via the different
layers first the start symbol appears on the wire this causes the file chip to erase the rxdv line
indicating that there is an incoming frame then signals are converted to data bytes however the first byte of this
data isn't actually the layer two bytes that you're used to seeing in infinite frames in wireshark
but rather they begin with the pre-order sequence and the start of frame delivering sfd byte the value of this byte is d5
the cpu when seeing the rxdv line go high starts waiting for an sfd byte on the rxd port
all bytes from that all bytes before that are treated as the preamble after these
initial bikes comes with similar layer 2 payload which is the ethernet frame stopping from its headers and up to the
payload when the error frame symbol arrives on the wire the rxdv line goes low and indicates a sip to the cpu that the
last four data bytes are again not actually data but rather a crc32 of the entire receive frame
the most important thing to note is what verifies the crc32 this fcs is actually the cpu rather than the
fight chip meaning potentially corrupted frames may arrive all this way to the cpu without being dropped on the way
so now let's see why this design is susceptible to a pakistani period attack suppose the sfd of a packet got not

the cpu sees the rxdv line go high and starts looking for an sfd byte it won't find

that specifies their shielding utp means unshielding and ftp and stp cables
do have shielding now any of these cables can be just as faulty as any other it's just not as equally likely from
what we've seen though the main parameter determining the likelihood of a fault is actually the length of the cable
so what's inside those cables really a utp cable is basically just four tightly twisted pairs of wires
running the length of the cable if we oversimplify a bit each of the two wires in each pair
will be always set to the opposite voltage of the other wire and the signal is the difference between
the voltages a positive difference is a one bit and a negative difference is a zero bit in this way any outside interference
should affect both wires of the pair in the same way at the same time therefore
whatever in the interference the difference between the wires should remain the same and the signal should remain intact
but as is the case with everything in nature those twisted pairs are are not perfect and therefore stp and
ftp cables have additional shielding to further prevent interference and any further imperfection beyond that in such
cables allows weaker and weaker interference to get through and damage the signal
